factoid: The whole hunting party was at the porch in an hour's time.
Nicholas had a stern and serious air.
Nicholas had no time for attending to trifles.
Nicholas went past Natásha and Pétya who were trying to tell him something.
Nicholas looked at all the details of the hunt.
Nicholas sent a pack of hounds and huntsmen ahead to find the quarry.
Nicholas mounted his chestnut Donéts.
Nicholas whistled to his own leash of borzois.
Nicholas set off across the threshing ground to a field leading to the Otrádnoe wood.
The old count’s horse, a sorrel gelding called Viflyánka, was led by the groom in attendance on him.
The count himself was to drive in a small trap straight to a spot reserved for him.
The hunting party was taking fifty-four hounds, with six hunt attendants and whippers-in.
The hunting party had eight borzoi kennelmen and more than forty borzois.
The hunting party had about a hundred and thirty dogs and twenty horsemen.
Each dog in the hunting party knew its master and its call.
Each man in the hunting party knew his business, his place, and what he had to do.
After passing the fence, the hunting party spread out evenly and quietly along the road and field leading to the Otrádnoe covert.
The horses stepped over the field as over a thick carpet.
The horses sometimes splashed into puddles as they crossed a road.
The misty sky seemed to descend evenly and imperceptibly toward the earth.
The air was still, warm, and silent.
Occasionally the whistle of a huntsman could be heard.
Occasionally the snort of a horse could be heard.
Occasionally the crack of a whip could be heard.
Occasionally the whine of a straggling hound could be heard.
After going a little less than a mile, five more riders with dogs appeared out of the mist, approaching the Rostóvs.
In front rode a fresh-looking, handsome old man with a large gray mustache.
Nicholas said “Good morning, Uncle!” when the old man drew near.
The old man was a distant relative of the Rostóvs, a man of small means, and their neighbor.
The old man said “I was sure of it.”
The old man said “I knew you wouldn’t be able to resist it and it’s a good thing you’re going.”
The old man said “Take the covert at once, for my Gírchik says the Ilágins are at Kornikí with their hounds.”
The old man said “They’ll take the cubs from under your very nose.”
The old man said “That’s where I’m going. Shall we join up our packs?” to Nicholas.
The hounds were joined into one pack.
The old man and Nicholas rode on side by side.
Natásha galloped up to them, muffled up in shawls which did not hide her eager face and shining eyes.
Natásha was followed by Pétya who always kept close to her.
Natásha was followed by Michael, a huntsman.
Natásha was followed by a groom appointed to look after her.
Pétya was laughing, whipped, and pulled at his horse.
Natásha sat easily and confidently on her black Arábchik and reined him in without effort with a firm hand.
The old man looked round disapprovingly at Pétya and Natásha.
The old man did not like to combine frivolity with the serious business of hunting.
Pétya shouted “Good morning, Uncle! We are going too!”
The old man said “Good morning, good morning! But don’t go overriding the hounds.”
Natásha said “Nicholas, what a fine dog Truníla is! He knew me.”
Truníla is a harrier, not a dog.
Nicholas thought Truníla is not a dog but a harrier.
Nicholas looked sternly at his sister to make her feel the distance that ought to separate them.
Natásha understood Nicholas’s intent.
Natásha said “You mustn’t think we’ll be in anyone’s way, Uncle.”
Natásha said “We’ll go to our places and won’t budge.”
The old man said “A good thing too, little countess, only mind you don’t fall off your horse.”
The old man added “because—that’s it, come on!—you’ve nothing to hold on to.”
